page.title: 05Birdwatching on the marshes.
page.content: {Birdwatching}can be disappointing on the{Manxey Levels.}There may be days when only a few{crows}can be seen. It is worth several visits armed with a pair of binoculars, as{mute swans}may fly into the area,{lapwings}arrive in great numbers and{mallards}arrive in pairs. These three breeds have nesting sites there,{Herons}also inhabit the banks of the draining ditches. If the area towards the sea is scanned there may be glimpses of less common birds,{ {plovers, curlews}and{grebes}- even a{ {red kite,}unfortunately found dead.{ {Barn owls}nest in nearby farms, and a farmer has spotted a visiting{hoopoe} on his land.{Fieldfares}and{redwings} sometimes stay briefly, seeking refuge in severe weather. More kestrels are seen hovering above the marshes, and are now breeding here and the visitor can readily see and hear the busy{lark
